skill.name: jira-safe
skill.description: Implement SAFe methodology in Jira. Use when creating Epics, Features, Stories with proper hierarchy, acceptance criteria, and parent-child linking.
skill.summary: Implement SAFe methodology in Jira. Use when creating Epics, Features, Stories with proper hierarchy...

security_audit.summary: Legitimate Jira integration skill implementing SAFe methodology. Static scanner produced 523 findings but 95% are false positives from pattern-matching markdown documentation. Network calls target Atlassian Jira endpoints only. Credentials stored in environment variables per security best practices. No credential exfiltration, code execution vulnerabilities, or malicious patterns detected.

content.user_title: Create SAFe-compliant Jira issues with hierarchy
content.value_statement: Managing Jira issues with proper SAFe hierarchy is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides templates and automation for creating Epics, Stories, and Subtasks with correct parent-child linking and Atlassian Document Format descriptions.
actual_capabilities: Create Epics with business outcomes, success metrics, and scope sections
Write user stories in SAFe format with Given-When-Then acceptance criteria
Link Stories to Epics using parent field for Next-Gen projects
Create Subtasks under Stories with proper hierarchy
Transition issues through workflow states (To Do, Progressing, Done)
Build Atlassian Document Format descriptions for rich text content
limitations: Requires Jira Cloud account with API access token
Works only with Next-Gen (Team-managed) or Classic (Company-managed) Jira projects
Does not modify existing issues - only creates new ones
Rate limited to 10 requests per second by Jira API

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Backlogs
use_cases.description: Create consistent Epic-Story-Subtask hierarchy across multiple teams using SAFe templates

use_cases.title: Plan Feature Releases
use_cases.description: Break down features into Stories with acceptance criteria and link them to parent Epics

use_cases.title: Track Sprint Work
use_cases.description: Create subtasks for technical work and transition issues through workflow states

prompt_templates.title: Create Epic
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Epic for [initiative name] with business outcome '[outcome]', success metrics [metrics], and scope description. Use SAFe format.

prompt_templates.title: Write Story
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a SAFe user story for '[feature]'. Include Given-When-Then acceptance criteria and Definition of Done.

prompt_templates.title: Add Subtasks
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 5 subtasks under Story [KEY] for [implementation steps]. Use technical task names.

prompt_templates.title: Full Hierarchy
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Epic with 3 Stories. Each Story should have 4 Subtasks. Use this specification: [details].

output_examples.input: Create an Epic for a new authentication system with business outcome 'Users can securely access their accounts', success metrics of 99.9% uptime and <100ms login time, and scope including login, logout, and password reset.
output: Summary: [Epic] Authentication System - Users can securely access their accounts
Business Outcome: Users can securely access their accounts
Scope: Login, logout, password reset flows

output_examples.input: Write a SAFe user story for user authentication including login, logout, and password reset scenarios
output: Story Summary: US-001: As a website visitor, I want to authenticate with email and password, so that I can access my account securely
- Scenario: Successful login with valid credentials
GIVEN user is on login page
WHEN user enters valid email and password
THEN user is redirected to dashboard
Definition of Done: [ ] Code reviewed, [ ] Tests passing, [ ] Documentation updated

best_practices: Always get user approval before creating Jira issues
Use parent field for Epic linking in Next-Gen projects
Include Definition of Done in every Story
anti_patterns: Using hardcoded credentials instead of environment variables
Skipping project type detection (Next-Gen vs Classic)

faq.question: Does this skill work with Classic Jira projects?
faq.answer: Yes. Use customfield_10014 for Epic Link and customfield_10011 for Epic Name. Detect project type first.

faq.question: How many issues can I create at once?
faq.answer: Jira allows approximately 10 requests per second. Add 100ms delays between bulk operations.

faq.question: Can I use this with on-premise Jira Server?
faq.answer: Yes. Update JIRA_BASE_URL to point to your on-premise instance. API endpoints remain the same.

faq.question: Is my credential data safe?
faq.answer: Credentials are stored in environment variables and sent only to Atlassian servers via HTTPS.

faq.question: Why are my issues not linking correctly?
faq.answer: Check if you are using Next-Gen or Classic project type. Next-Gen uses parent field; Classic uses customfield_10014.

faq.question: What is the difference between Epics, Features, and Stories?
faq.answer: Epics are strategic initiatives at portfolio level. Features are benefit hypotheses. Stories deliver user value. Subtasks break down technical work.
